questions.question_text:
A project team was hired to perform on-site duties, but there were unexpected circumstances that required the entire team to work remotely. Some team members returned to their hometowns, and they are now requesting reimbursement for operational expenditures.
What should the project manager do?

choices.B: Update the project management plan with the incurred costs.
choices.C: Ask the team members to draft a justification before processing the reimbursements.
choices.A: Review the budget and allocate funds for the reimbursements.
choices.D: Follow the Perform Integrated Change Control process and submit a change request.

discussion.content: Follow the Perform Integrated Change Control process and submit a change request. This ensures that the decision to reimburse operational expenditures is documented and approved within the project's formal change management process. It helps maintain transparency and control over budget adjustments, ensuring all stakeholders are informed and onboard with the changes. Keeping the project management plan updated with these changes is crucial for accuracy and accountability. Sensible approach, right?

Selected Answer: C
C. Ask the team members to draft a justification before processing the reimbursements.

Before processing any reimbursements, it's important for the project manager to understand the nature of the operational expenditures and why they were incurred. By asking the team members to draft a justification, the project manager can ensure that the expenses were necessary and directly related to the unexpected circumstances that required remote work. This helps in maintaining accountability and transparency within the project team. Once the justifications are provided, the project manager can then proceed with reviewing the budget and processing reimbursements if deemed appropriate.

Selected Answer: D
The project manager should choose option **D. Follow the Perform Integrated Change Control process and submit a change request**.

In project management, any changes to the project scope, schedule, or costs should go through the Integrated Change Control process. This process ensures that all impacts of the change are considered and approved by the appropriate stakeholders before being implemented. In this case, the change in work location and the associated operational expenditures are changes that could impact the project's budget and need to be formally addressed.

Please note that this is a general advice and the best course of action may vary depending on the specific circumstances and the organizational structure.

I believe they are, lets look at the options:
A. Changed the duration of iterations to deliver more value
You can't do this without change board approval
B. Validated the iteration goals with the customer
This has a grammatical error but it seems to be what you would do next, you want to check if you can make the goals with an altered schedule.
C. Invited the customer to the daily meetings
A customer doesn't really attend "daily meetings" (standup meetings) very often, The purpose of these is just to get an idea of what your goals for the day are, and if you have anything impeding your progress for either today or from yesterday. (Since they usually take place before work)
D. Helped the team redefine the MVP
The team never defines the minimum viable product, this is something that is done by the product owner/customer in agile, the team just performs work, they don't create the work (otherwise you run into issues like gold plating, scope creep, etc.)
